their patrons ride charming scooters or performance bikes.
i drive a yuppie scum BMW from BMW of san francisco.

but regardless of hipster or yuppie scum, we're all brought together by a love of excellent coffee.  and that's enough to overcome my lack of hipness.
author: brian w.

description: Glad to see there's a place to get Blue Bottle around South Park. My addiction will not abate. It's very similar to the Blue Bottle kiosk in Hayes Valley. The cookies are good too.
author: bill l.

description: This place is great. Recently had their "Cento" filled with smooth caffeinated goodness, highly recommended. The best is that I sipped it in the warmth and sunshine. How much better does life get?  With great drinks and super-friendly staff, Cento is highly recommended!
author: Kat D.

description:
one star for using good coffee beans. 

this place is ridiculous. it takes at least 5 minutes for them to make your coffee because they do it the prehistoric way with a bonfire and a strainer woven out of grass. its served scorching with major spillage, make sure you get napkins and a lawyer. 

yeah yeah yeah, everyone else loves this stuff just because of it's strange hipster cult following but i drink my coffee black and this crap is overrated.
author: Al I.

description: Awesome coffee. No decaf drip, but they do have decaf espresso drinks or americanos.  Great foam also.
author: Jen W.

description: So  I went back and tried the regular coffee which I guess is Blue Bottle? And I still don't get the hype.
author: Holly E.

description: If you're looking for quick, affordable, consistent drip coffee, this place is good.  Food is no where to be found  early in the morning, but they definitely scratch your caffine itch.  They play music as  you wait.  There's something cool about a no frills coffee joint located in an industrial alley that is appealing.  They have a full menu for lunch that I yet to try, but judging by the crowd it attracts, I've got to assume they're doing something right.
author: R B.

description: It's like I discovered a secret alley passage way to get my coffee fix. It's a cute and friendly kiosk which seems to share a kitchen with 330 Ritch. At $2 for drip coffee with blue bottle roasted beans, skip Borders across the street. Lattes are also very good. Looks like they serve lunch takeout food as well. Too bad they aren't open during the weekends!
author: Annie Y.

description: Best place in the city to get Blue Bottle coffee. Staff is cute and sweet. I love these ladies . . . and few gentlemen.  If I've got a few minutes to spare before going into the office, I'll do everything I can to swing by. After one double Americano I'm ready to put out any number of fires and power through the 200 emails waiting in my inbox.
author: Courtney H.

description: John's "American-style" macchiato is unassailably perfect.
author: Abie H.

description: You can't go wrong with Cento. I recommend the New Orleans iced coffee on a hot day.
author: Johnnie M.

description: I am so through with the pretentiousness of the whole Blue Bottle thing.  My 2nd visit to a Blue Bottle place and the staff were just as snooty and the space was just as uninviting.  I ordered a cappuccino and asked for it "on the dry side" because I'm sick of baristas ruining caps by making them lattes with a little extra foam.  Its 1/3 espresso, 1/3 steamed milk, 1/3 foam, pretty much has been since they were invented in the 1900s.  Anyway, the uppity hipster who served me looked at me through her thick black hipster glasses and said in a tone you might use when talking with the mentally challenged "oh no, I don't think I can do that" and then proceeded to give me a lecture on how to make caps.  I haven't been a barista, but have made probably 3-400 caps at my last place of work, so I kinda know what is and isn't possible.  She convinced me to try it her way, which was 1/3 espresso and the rest foamed milk.  It was good, as a latte, which was on the menu and which wasn't what I wanted.  Long story short, Blue Bottle get over yourself (and learn to give the customer what they want).  Philz gives better service, better coffee and a nice space to enjoy it in instead of huddled on some stupid alley.
author: Mike B.

description: Cento started making pressed sandwiches.  We got the ham and cheese and the one with the pickled peppers.  They were both cold in the middle.  I make a saddy face.  At least the coffee is still awesome.
author: Lorin Y.

description: I love this place. It's one of those unexpected finds in SF. I'm from New Orleans, and while the thought of paying $3.50 for an iced coffee makes me in my coffee pot, the drip is a steal. Doesn't hurt that there's a severe cutie working there =)
author: Kevin L.

description: I can't believe it's taken me this long to write a review about this place. It's definitely my first stop in the morning before work, and it's only a block away, tucked in Ritch alley. I wouldn't call this a cafe or coffee shop so much as a hole in the wall that serves coffee and espresso drinks, but appearances can be deceiving. I've never been to such an unassuming, friendly coffee joint that serves such awesome coffee. Seriously, this coffee IS awesome. Although I have my Blue Bottle bean preferences (thanks to this place), you can never get a bad cup of joe here, and I hear the lattes are excellent too; I know for a fact that at least the latte art is!
author: Ryan C.

description: Yay! Blue Bottle Coffee in the hood - so 'cited. You will now see me here spending too much money for coffee several times each day. Totally worth it. Baristas are totally cool too...welcome to the block Cento...
author: Kate S.

description: The new cafe space downtown behind the old Mint building is clean, simple, effectively designed.  It encourages conversation because of it.   Great place to catch up with complete strangers brought together by arguably the best espresso machine coffees in San Francisco.  I haven't tried the ultra modern coffees boiled by beams of light yet, but will someday.    Their espressos are in the same league as Europe, and there lattes are wonderful.  The way they whip/steam the milk is their secret, it's always very well done.
author: Roland C.

description: Fast and tasty! Very solid paninis.  Who doesn't love bean juice and/or cheese.
author: Sarah M.

description: These guys are awesome! the 9 people that ordered after me got their coffee before i did, and they got my order wrong. if it wasn't for their holier than thou attitudes then maybe i would consider giving them a new nickname. Scooter H03$!
author: tony p.

description: cute cafe with no seats. i am not a big fan of blue bottle so i won't comment on their lattes.  mew.
author: Moko R.

description:
tl;dr: Espresso drinks here are to die for.

Jun 08:
The New Orleans iced coffee I just got here wasn't anything like the other ones I've gotten from other Blue Bottle places...sigh. The New Orleans from the Temescal farmers' market last weekend was thick and creamy like chocolate milk, this one from Ritch St tasted like I put some Folgers in the fridge.

Hopefully it's a fluke. I'll go back and try a latte when it's not so hot out. 

Sep 08:
Bumped from 3 to 4 stars after having a couple espresso drinks...maybe my NOLA coffee really was a fluke? The owner of the space is great at pulling a shot, and is can almost draw the Prince symbol in your latte. Whoa.

Oct 08:
Had second NOLA coffee, and it was disappointing. 4 stars, but get drip or an espresso drink...there is always someone working there who can pull you a good shot.

Dec 08:
Been my morning stop for months at this point, and I have yet to be disappointed by a latte. Ella has crafted the best latte I've ever had. Still scared off the NOLA iced coffee, but it's too cold for that anyway. It's fun to talk about things on two wheels with the owner, John. I love that there's almost never a wait (used to go to Mint Plaza but got tired of waiting for 20 minutes).
author: Alexander Q.

description: Better Blue Bottle coffee than Blue Bottle.
author: Jay V.

description: Great coffee, strange hole in the wall location
author: A P.

description: Blue Bottle coffee in my 'hood.  'Nuff said, 5 Stars!
author: Johnny P.

description: good times had by all hanging in the alley sipping blue bottle here.  stop by and find a bench or curb to just relax on.  even when the entire block lost its electricity, hot coffee was served.  john q knows how to do it right.
author: Olis L.

description: i love them and they love me, or rather, my moped crew loves them and they love us! i'll be john's forever loyal customer, whether it cafe lambretta or cafe cento!
author: Jaei P.

description: The future of coffee bars.  Simple menu, excellent roaster, up to date baristas that know the science of pulling shots and preparing "specialty coffee".  It's amazing how Starbucks or Philz is still mentioned in the same sentence as these mini bars.  Starbucks is fully automatic, meaning there is no barista talent needed.  Their machines are pre-programmed to pull a shot (espresso) in a specific time.  But the time factor is only one of many variables that go into making a great espresso.  They are in business for sheer volume = money, sorta like McDonald's.   Philz is... well, it's Philz.  It's one man's creativity on coffee.  Not bad for sure.  But then again you eat California Rolls and there is no such thing in Japan.  Bars like Cento and the other 2 in the City are following a growing trend to revert back to true Italian style coffee.  Not the California Roll coffee 95% of all coffee houses and restaurants serve.  More than likely the reason you don't prefer it is because your brainwashed into thinking California Roll coffee is the ONLY coffee, over sweet, over foamed, over sized.  I read about a 1/3 1/3 1/3 ratio of espresso, steamed milk and foam making a cappuccino???  That ratio has been slowly dying and deserves to die.  Soon you'll be outta luck finding that ratio because the double shot with a light airy foam is what "specialty" coffee bars are serving now, and a latte has no foam! tsk tsk! but then again almost all reviews by this rater were negative so head to Cento and upgrade your palate to real espresso drinks using some of the best beans in town.  Oh and I'd rather have a consistently excellent espresso drink from someone that doesn't greet me like a car salesman then a fake american-style espresso drink that I'm regretting and just drinking for the caffeine...
author: No I Don't Have Time F.

description: Blue Bottle beans, Blue Bottle prices, bleh coffee.  Don't know how they're screwing it up, but the product is not up to Blue Bottle standards.
author: Jeff B.

description: I've been going to 4 barrels and ritual for my coffee even though I live in SOMA.  Then I found out about Cento.  The coffee here is excellent.  Up to par with the best in SF.  The only problem I have with this place is they close at 3pm, which means I almost never get a chance to have their coffee.  Personally, I think this is the best coffee in SOMA.  Definitely better than Epicenter and Blue Bottle in Mint Plaza (which I'm told is not their best representative).
author: Loc N.
